awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Production of Solar Quality Silicon by Model-Driven Molten Salt Electrolysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Silicon is the dominant solar material because of its abundance, low cost, and high solar efficiency.  But manufacturing high-purity silicon required for solar energy is very complex, hard to scale, and unsafe since it involves handling toxic flammable gases. This award lays the scientific foundations for a new solar silicon production technology based on molten salt electrolysis. This process uses high purity quartzite or silica as its raw material. By this method, the production cost of solar silicon is expected to fall from $10 per kg today to just $1-2 per kg.  The new silicon process uses significantly less energy than current practice and eliminates all direct CO₂ and related emissions. These advances in solar energy production technology contribute to the economic competitiveness of the U.S. solar industry.  The fundamental knowledge gained in this research can be used to devise similar novel environmentally sound and efficient production methods for high-melting refractory metals, as well as silicon carbide and other semiconducting materials. The project’s impact is also further broadened through published model data and code, educational modules developed from the research results, and student training in a collaborative and multidisciplinary environment which includes both computational and experimental work.

This project establishes four integrated mathematical models of the process based on new experimental data which help in the understanding of silicon molten salt electrolysis and its scale-up.  The first molten salt structure (MSS) model involves spectroscopic analysis coupled with atomistic models to understand the molecular structure of complex ions in the five-component molten salt.  The second CALculation of PHAse Diagrams (CALPHAD) model to understand and predict thermodynamic and thermophysical properties of the molten salt including silica solubility, silicon compound volatility and ion mobility.  These properties are experimentally validated and used in a third transport model to study the reaction and diffusion kinetics of silicon electrodeposition at the cathode-electrolyte interface to predict deposit structure and composition.  A fourth phase field model uses these molten salt properties to study the transport of silicon to the cathode and oxygen to the anode to understand boundary layer structure and improve the deposition rate.  Using these models, a new current wave-form switching system is developed to maintain stable dendrite-free silicon growth at high current density.  The new low-cost single operation silicon molten salt electrolysis replaces multiple energy-intensive unit operations of carbothermic silicon production, acid digestion, trichlorosilane synthesis, distillation, and chemical vapor deposition used in the current Siemens process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This linked collaborative project with Boston University sought fundamental insights about high-temperature electrodeposition of silicon from a novel molten salt electrolyte.  A very low-cost one-step zero-emissions process based on this work could potentially turn moderate purity silicon dioxide (SiO₂) sand to high-purity silicon suitable for solar or battery applications.

The electrolyte is based on magnesium fluoride, calcium fluoride and calcium oxide, three extremely stable compounds.  The combination has several properties which make it ideal for silicon electrodeposition: it melts around 950°C, with very low volatility and viscosity, excellent compatibility with oxygen-producing inert anodes, and high SiO₂ solubility.  The project planned to use experiments and computation to develop a set of four models of electrodeposition, studying the behavior of ions in the electrolyte, its thermodynamic properties, growth and mitigation of roughness on the growing silicon surface, and overall mass transfer in a large electrolysis cell.

In three years, the project team ran dozens of high-temperature electrochemistry experiments, and succeeded in building all of the models except for that of deposit surface roughness.  Experiments overcame multiple obstacles and deposited silicon.  In particular, when deposition began, a coating of magnesium oxide formed in the salt which we had not expected.  The team studied the salt thermodynamics and changed the salt composition, and also improved mass transfer in the cell, in order to solve this problem.  Then the deposited silicon formed dendrites, which are long thin branches emerging from the deposit, instead of the desired film coating of monolithic material.  To overcome this challenge, we recruited an electrical engineering undergraduate student, who designed and fabricated a high-frequency (kHz) pulse waveform generator.  But the resulting silicon deposits persistently had trapped salt, a problem we were not able to solve.

The team designed a scaled-up process for silicon production by molten salt electrodeposition, using electrolysis cells comparable to those which produce aluminum.  It would operate at 1000-1050°C, similar to aluminum, but with a solid silicon product cf. liquid aluminum.  The configuration would grow plates of silicon, on a silicon substrate.  Our model of electric current, fluid flow, and heat and mass transfer indicates that magnetohydrodinamics stirring, driven by the electric current and plant magnetic field, should provide sufficient flow to grow silicon plates at a rate per unit of cell footprint area which is comparable to that of aluminum production.  Two PhD theses and multiple journal and conference publications describe the experiments above and the models which helped us to make this progress.

On a more minute scale, the project explored the interactions of magnesium, calcium, silicon, fluorine and oxygen ions in the liquid state.  For the past thirty years, there have been two types of models of individual atoms and molecules, known by the broad name of molecular dynamics (MD).  One of them called "ab initio" MD (AIMD) calculated the details of electron cloud probability distributions, in order to get detailed understanding of how bonding occurred between pairs or very small groups of atoms.  The other, called "classical" MD, i.e. Interatomic Potential-based Molecular Dynamics (IPMD), used coarse approximations to study how large numbers of atoms interacted with each other, simulating millions of atoms but with deficiencies in accuracy.  This project used a hybrid of these two: an artificial intelligence (AI) system studied results of ab initio studies, and provided a reliable and efficient alternative for molecular dynamics simulations.

The results validated the accuracy of MD in predicting key structural and transport properties, including radial distribution functions, ionic diffusivities, densities, and viscosities, with strong agreement between simulation methods and experimental data.  By leveraging Neural Network Interatomic Potentials (NNIPs), the study enabled large-scale MD simulations that would otherwise be computationally prohibitive using purely AIMD methods.  For example, the findings highlight the well-mixed nature of CaF₂-MgF₂ with no short-range order or ion clustering, offering valuable insight into its behavior at high temperatures.  The successful validation of this new MD approach not only advances the understanding of molten fluoride systems but also establishes a scalable computational approach for studying complex high-temperature materials, particularly in applications like silicon electrodeposition where experimental validation is challenging.  These results contribute to the broader field of high-temperature materials science, supporting the development of new functional materials for energy and electrochemical applications.  The MgF₂-CaF₂ system work was published in a journal article, with oxide and silicate ion addition to follow in one or more publications and a PhD thesis in 2025.

In summary, the project succeeded in nearly all of its goals in studying the fundamentals of electrochemistry in this novel molten salt system.  And it laid the scientific foundation for what may become the lowest-cost and lowest-emissions method for making pure silicon.
